1.trip_description: Discover the Basque coast and its treasures on both sides of the border.

hops.hop_description: Catch a train from Montparnasse Station down to the perfect place to start a discovery of Basque Country.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Yann Caradec from Paris, France, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: The ideal introduction to what makes the Basque country (on both sides of the border) great. Great food, great architecture, fascinating history and plenty of opportunities to immerse yourself.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Koudkeu, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Take the train, bus or even walk to the twin-town Biarritz where you can catch some surf, or explore the genteel parts and find out why Edward VII liked to spend so much time here.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Pelalion, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Another great resort with a great beach - compare and contrast with Biarritz. Other options are Hendaye and Hondarribia.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Harrieta171, CC BY-SA 3.0 <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/>, via Wikimedia Commons
hops.link_text: Saint Jean de Luz Tourist Information

hops.hop_description: Being just 20km from the French border, San Sebastian (Donostia in Basque) is an ideal hop off when travelling to Spain. Where better to top up your tan, fill up your tummy and empty your wallet in this seductively urbane resort? Probably the most difficult decision you will have to make here is which of the beaches to choose from?
hops.hop_image_attribution: Miguel Ángel García. from Ólvega., España, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: An authentic Basque town off the tourist trail. Why not while away an hour or two wandering around the historic quarter with it's neat Basque townhouses and the odd grand pile like the high-gothic church of Santa María which leads to the covered market place for rainy days.
hops.hop_image_attribution: EGIZU Getxo Euskaldun Elkartea from Getxo, Euskal Herria, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Capital of the Basque Autonomous Community. In the medieval quarter, the Gothic-style Santa María Cathedral features a sculpted facade and towering columns.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Zarateman, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Sometimes referred to as the City of the Guggenheim, what better place to take in culture, fhistory and fine food.
hops.hop_image_attribution: PA, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

2.trip_description: Why rush to Barca when there's so much to see en-route?

hops.hop_description: Start in the city of light catching a train from Gare de Lyon, how to get there? Here are some ideas for crossing Paris?
hops.hop_image_attribution: Yann Caradec from Paris, France, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: The world heritage city of Avignon is a gem. It's only been part of France since the Revolution and has a rich history which you can see find out by going for a walk. The slow train to Portbou has some great scenery.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Jean-Marc Rosier from http://www.rosier.pro, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: The small border town of Portbou is a great place to go for a wander when changing trains. Visit the moving monument to Walter Benjamin and then go for a paddle. The previous stop, Cerbere on the French side of the border is also a possible place to change - if you fancy going over the hill, there are some great views.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Jcb-caz-11, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: With around 20 million tourists per year, Barcelona is on the popular side...But it's with good reason. It's a sophisticated beach-side party town with world class architecture and there's always a festival of some sort on.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Yeagov, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

3.trip_description: Discover the favourite places and less well-known gems of Brittany

hops.hop_description: Port city with tall granite walls surround the old town, which was once a stronghold for privateers.
hops.hop_image_attribution: via Wikicommons

hops.hop_description: Pretty Breton town with long history and a massive 7,000 year old standing stone. William the Conqueror failed to take the town and had to settle for England.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Richard Mudhar via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Hop off at the historic town of Lannion, the capital of Trégor and the gateway to the Pink Granite Coast.
hops.hop_image_attribution: WikiLaurent at English Wikipedia, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Nearby Morlaix is further along the Pink Granite Coast.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Thesupermat, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Landerneau in the bay of Brest, with the famous Rohan bridge, the only bridge in Europe that still has people living on it.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Ghouston, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Paris to Venice is Orient Express levels of iconic train travel, but why not have a cultural feast on the way?
hops.hop_image_attribution: Renegade at Dutch Wikipedia, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

4.trip_title: Explore Charantes Maritime - Ile de Re
4.trip_description: Explore the delights of Charantes Maritime

hops.hop_description:
Take the train from Gare Montparnasse to head for the Charante-Maritime. First stop - La Rochelle

Find out more
hops.hop_image_attribution: Yann Caradec from Paris, France, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: La Rochelle, capital of Charente-Maritime and one of the most livable cities in France, is a pretty good place to go and get nautical. If you want action, why not take to the waves on a catamaran? Or if you'd rather keep your feet on the ground, you could go for a wander around La Ville Blanche (as La Rochelle is known) and get some great views by climbing the two towers that used to protect the harbour from the troublesome English.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Remi Jouan, CC BY-SA 3.0 <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Head to the heady island of Ile de Re - a place with the perfect weather for harvesting salt and nurturing oysters.
Head back to La Rochelle, and catch a train or bus to Saintes for some Roman gems.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Remi Jouan, CC BY-SA 3.0 <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Saintes may come second to La Rochelle in terms of size but it's firmly number one for Roman architecture. A great place for a wander.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Ralph Capper, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

5.trip_description: Here's an alternative way into the heart of Charentes Maritime.

hops.hop_description: From La Rochelle to catch a bus to Ile d'Oleron. If you take a boat from the harbour, you get to go past Fort Boyard
hops.hop_image_attribution: Remi Jouan, CC BY-SA 3.0 <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Take your time loafing around the fine Ile d'Oleron.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Remi Jouan, CC BY-SA 3.0 <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Pop over to Poitiers and admire the intricately carved facade on the Église Notre-Dame la Grande. At Christmas and on summer evenings, the church features a colorful light show. The Palace of Poitiers, now home to the city's courthouse, features the Salle des Pas Perdus, a cavernous assembly hall with massive fireplaces.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Luca Aless, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

6.trip_description: Visit some of the finest Roman sites in France

hops.hop_description: There isn't much Roman stuff left in Paris, apart from Les Arenes To see something on a grander scale, head over to Gare de Lyon. First stop - Orange
hops.hop_image_attribution: Mbzt, CC BY 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: The local tourist board isn't wrong when is says 'You will be amazed by the quality of the Roman monuments that you will see in Orange. The Roman amphitheatre and the Triumphal Arch, both listed as World Heritage Sites by UNESCO. Other sites include temples on Saint Eutrope Hill as well as part of the city walls, the aqueduct and the western wall of the forum.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Andim, CC BY-SA 3.0 <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Arles' amphitheatre and nearby theatre are world class Roman sites, but it was the necroplolis that caught Vincent van Gogh's eye. It was the first place he took Gauguin to to capture the atmosphere
hops.hop_image_attribution: PierreSelim, CC BY 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: If you were wow'ed by Arles, then Nimes' amphitheatre will blow your socks off. The Maison Carree is also UNESCO listed as a treasure. Wandering up to the Tour Magne, the last remains of the Roman walls, through the Jardins des Fontaines gives a sense of continuity with the past.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Krzysztof Golik, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

7.trip_description: In 1888, Vincent van Gogh made a train trip that would, arguaby, set the future direction of art. Let's follw his path and see what it brings.

hops.hop_description: In January 1888, Vincent van Gogh was living in Paris with his brother trying to forge a career in art, with little sucess. If he had stayed here, we may never have heard of him. But he decided to head south with a vague idea of going to Marseille and then somehow on to Japan. But all this changed when he got off the train at Arles. Let's follow that journey and see if we can see through his eyes what made him the painter he became. By the way, you can see van Gogh's works at the Musée d'Orsay. The appartment he stayed in with his brother isn't open for public access, but you can still wander around Montmartre and soak up some of the atmosphere.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Vincent van Gogh, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: In February 1888, Vincent van Gogh got off the train at Arles (in the snow) and spend a frantic 9 months painting and drawing. You can wander around the town and see what caught his imagination.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Vincent van Gogh, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

8.trip_description: Let's follow in the footsteps of Salvador Dali who left his home town of Figueres to make his name in Paris - and when he was famous, went back home again...

hops.hop_description: You can see a collection of his works at Dali Paris in Monmartre
hops.hop_image_attribution: Carl Van Vechten, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Later in life, Dali returned to Figueres and set up the Theatre Museum - probably the best place to get into the mind of Dali. From Figueres, you can catch a bus to his home at Portllegat  - just a short walk from Cadaques
hops.hop_image_attribution: Erin Silversmith, GFDL <http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/fdl.html>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Cadaqués and the adjoining fishing village of Portllegat was where Dali built his seaside home, which is now a museum.
hops.hop_image_attribution: 5snake5, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

9.trip_description: Belgium is world famous for beer, but it's also the original source of gin.

hops.hop_description: Start in the Capital where you could try out the popular bars around La Grande Place. Want some guidance? Why not try a beer tour?
hops.hop_image_attribution: Dirk Van Esbroeck, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: To really understand the Belgian love of beer you'll need to take a trip out to Beersel. This is where geuze is produced. 3 fontainen and Oude Beersel are great breweries to do some sampling. Why not go for a wobbly walk around the top-notch medieval castle afterwards?
hops.hop_image_attribution: Tomixdf via wikicommons

hops.hop_description: Belgians don't just drink beer. They also have a soft spot for a drop of jenever - gin's older cousin. Catch the train down to the Hasselt, where the fine stuff is made. There's a museum with very friendly staff. On the outskirts of the town is 't Stookkot http://www.stookkot.be/ - a distillery run by savvy enthusiasts that makes fantastic spelt jenever.
hops.hop_image_attribution: jenevermuseum

10.trip_description: The train from Hamburg to Copenhagen takes you through the gentle coutryside of Schleswig Holstein and over Odense - so many places to visit on the way back. Arriving in Copenhagen  - hire a bike and pedal around the town and see how it makes sense as part of a Northern whole.

hops.hop_description: Catch the train to Brussels Midi where you could just change trains or grab a bite to eat and a belgian beer from the nearby Saint Gilles district where you could also check out the Art Nouveau buildings- you could even meet a greeter who will take you for a guided tour of there home town.

Why not hop off the train at Aachen on the way to Cologne and go for a wander or hire a bike and cycle to a different country. Three corner point between Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands is just a leg-stretch away. For a quirky bit of history why not cycle along the Vennbahn? Stay ovoernight and have an evening spa session at the Carolus Thermal baths.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Wi1234, CC BY-SA 3.0 <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: The massive gothic cathedral is hard to miss in Cologne, so it's handy that it's next to the station - why not go for a wander around the cobbled old town or pick up a hire bike or scooter and go for a peddle/scoot along the banks of the Rhine. The steady stream of cargo boats are a reminder of how this town got rich and the importance of trade.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Martin Falbisoner, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: When it comes to prosperous trading cities, Hanseatic Hamburg has a long proud pedigree. It's used its money wisely and built stunning architecture, but it's also left space for parks and gardens which make strolling and cycling a real pleasure. Altona, now a district of Hamburg used to belong to the Danish Crown. Alt Zu Nar! - Far too close, the locals would say, or Altona as it became, supposedly.
hops.hop_image_attribution: NielsFahrenkrog, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: After cycling around Hamburg, Cologne and Aachen, Copenhagen will in many ways feel very familiar. On the way back, you could why not stop at one of these places: Odense, Flensburg, Lubeck, Bremen or Osnabruck?
hops.hop_image_attribution: Scythian, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

11.trip_description: Discover what's beyond the Straits of Messina.

hops.hop_description: All roads lead from Rome. Take train down to Agrigento, stopping at some great sights on the way.

We're down in what was Norman country, so why not stat with a visit to the Norman Messina Cathedral, with its Gothic portal, 15th-century windows and an astronomical clock on the bell tower. Nearby are marble fountains decorated with mythological figures, like the Fontana di Orione, with its carved inscriptions, and the Neptune Fountain, topped by a statue of the sea god.
hops.hop_image_attribution: kajikawa, CC BY 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Hop off at the ancient port city that sits at the foot of Mt. Etna. You can take one of the trails leading up to the summit. Afterwards, visit the Piazza del Duomo with the whimsical Fontana dell'Elefante statue and richly decorated Catania Cathedral. In the southwest corner of the square, La Pescheria weekday fish market is a rowdy spectacle surrounded by seafood restaurants.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Castielli, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: For a dramatic location with great views, hop off at Enna.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Leandro Neumann Ciuffo, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Arrive in the hilltop city of Agrigento on Sicily's southwest shore. It's known for the ruins of the ancient city of Akragas in the Valley of the Temples, a vast archaeological site with well-preserved Greek temples. On the modern city's outskirts is the Museo Archeologico Regionale 'Pietro Griffo', with artifacts and a telamon (giant male figure). West lies Scala dei Turchi, a stepped white cliff overlooking sandy beaches.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Berthold Werner, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

12.trip_description: It's easy to forget that the Greek world used to stretch around the Mediterranean and some places ended up with the same name. For Greek ruins, Naples is a good place to go, but visiting Gallipoli at the southern tip of Italy brings that legacy to life. Why? Many of the local still speak Griko - a Greek dialect.

hops.hop_description: Let's start in the modern captial and wend our way down to see some ancient stuff. First stop Taranto.
Hop off at Taranto and take a tour of the Spartan Museum. The 15th-century Aragonese castle is a reminder that others from elsewhere in the Med have had their time here.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Livioandronico2013, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Wander around the historic cente taking in the sights and sounds with, of course a stroll to the Greek fountain.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Lupiae, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

13.trip_description: Head to the eternal city taking in a choice selection of things from the cultural feast of northern Italy on the way.

hops.hop_description: Start in Paris and catch the train to Turin. If you feel you are missing too much on the way, why not stop off at Chambery.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Kainet, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: After taking in this disticntly differernt slice of Italy, why not book yourself Pasta and Tiramisu class
Pick wherever you like from the UNESCO Cinque Terre  - a string of five picturesque villages clinging to the cliffs along the Italian Riviera.
Take THE iconic shot in Pisa - then notice that all the other buildings look like they are on a wonk as well. May it's the ground that's squiffy - or maybe you...
hops.hop_image_attribution: © José Luiz Bernardes Ribeiro

hops.hop_description: Head for Florence to keep the culture coming.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Architas, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Head for Rome, the grandest of destinations.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Thomas Wolf, www.foto-tw.de, CC BY-SA 3.0 DE <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/de/deed.en>, via Wikimedia Commons

14.trip_description: Head to the eternal city taking in a choice selection of things from the cultural feast of northern Italy on the way.

hops.hop_description: Start in Paris and catch the train to Turin. If you feel you are missing too much on the way, why not stop off at Chambery.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Kainet, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Turin
hops.hop_image_attribution: Gianni Careddu, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Milan
hops.hop_image_attribution: Marco Pagani, CC BY 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Verona
hops.hop_image_attribution: Didier Descouens, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Venice
hops.hop_image_attribution: Kent Wang from Barcelona, Spain, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

15.trip_description: Head to Venice and Vienna using night trains

hops.hop_description: Start in Paris or Brussels. The night jet runs from each destination on alternate nights.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Kainet, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Arrive in Vienna first thing in the morning and spend the day in the city leaving your bags in a locker Or spend a night or two here.
hops.hop_image_attribution: © Jorge Royan / http://www.royan.com.ar

hops.hop_description: Venice
hops.hop_image_attribution: Kent Wang from Barcelona, Spain, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

16.trip_description: Use night trains to head deep into Transylvania.

hops.hop_description: Catch the train to Brussels Midi and then catch a night train to Vienna - you could use Paris instead as a starting point.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Francisco Conde Sánchez, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Arrive in Vienna first thing in the morning and spend the day in the city leaving your bags in a locker Or spend a night or two here.
hops.hop_image_attribution: © Jorge Royan / http://www.royan.com.ar

hops.hop_description: Arrive in Budapest. Enjoy the ciy before catching a night train down to Bucarest. Sibiu and Brasov are great places to stop on the way.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Jorge Franganillo from Barcelona, Spain, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Arrive in Brasov.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Nicolmiron, CC BY-SA 3.0 RO <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ro/deed.en>, via Wikimedia Commons

17.trip_description: Catch a glimpse of the the old Austro-Hungarian Empire by travelling between its twin seats of power - Vienna and Budapest.

hops.hop_description: Arrive in Vienna first thing in the morning and spend the day in the city leaving your bags in a locker Or spend a night or two here.
hops.hop_image_attribution: © Jorge Royan / http://www.royan.com.ar

hops.hop_description: Travel to the capital of Slovakia and stroll around it's medieval Old Town, Bratislava Castle, and Devin Castle to pick up the Hapsburg vibes.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Rob Hurson from Kentstown, Ireland, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Hop to the elegant city of Gyor which has become somthing of a cultural hub.
hops.hop_image_attribution: User:Slashme, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Move on to the historic Danube town of Estergom - one of the oldest towns in Hungary
hops.hop_image_attribution: Villy, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

hops.hop_description: Arrive in Budapest with its grand imperial buildings, layered history and diverse districts that don't neatly fit with stereotypes.
hops.hop_image_attribution: Jorge Franganillo from Barcelona, Spain, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
